lg.l: The rebel at Port Royal"'Broad River' and 'Fort Walker' were equally available metrically, and geographically as precise. But only 'Port Royal' starts the series of associations linked with Blaise Pascal, whose genius encompassed both mathematics and the science of ethics, who mastered the elements of Euclid's geometry by himself as a child and whose life was so closely connected with the moral precisions of the Jansenists at Port-Royal." The UnityThe poem's meter is iambic with fourteen syllables per line; the only variation is for the word "Unity," which adds an extra syllable. Melville's theme of perfection extends itself beyond the mathematical; it is cosmological, a moment where the wishes of man and Providence of God are in perfect unison. As Stanton Garner writes, "The ships at Port Royal 'in an orbit sailed' as they fought for the right, the unity, and the law of the covenant of America with God" (124). overawe,
